name: Words for Evil
description: Words for Evil is a fast paced word game combined with a fantasy RPG. It features everything you expect from an RPG, including combat, hero progression, loot and more, all built on top of word game mechanics.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: 2.0 GHz Intel Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: GeForce 8800 or Radeon® HD4800 series, 512 MB DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 500 MB available space

reviews.review_text: So this game taught me that you can indeed hurt people with words. 11/10

I don't like giving 'not recommended' reviews, but technically this game has the complexity of 'TRIGGER KNIGHT' from Kongregate, except you have to type in words to do damage instead of pressing a simple button. Considering how quickly enemies attack and how often you die to give it a roguelike-but-heroprogression feel (unless you look up the anagrams on the internet in the background), typing random words hopefully 3-4-5 letters long that you hope are on the grid is the way to go. After 4 hours, I don't really want to return to it. But I did get 2 EUR worth of time out of it, I guess. I don't like the time limits on the anagram system though, who the hell thinks of words like ICARIAN, JAMDANI, APOCOPE or NONYLIC? (or my favorite that the anagram finders didn't know - SAGATHY) And if you don't, your character is dead. Didn't like that mechanic, because I'm bad at it, and it just feels unreasonable.  The problem with the game is how the letters are not organized in any reasonable shape or form on the grid, so finding words really just comes down to typing in random permutations of letters you see quickly and hope the game accepts it.  You can buy it, it's interesting at first, but it's a one-trick pony. If you want a one-trick pony that's a bit more versatile, go for either Trigger Knight, or Puzzle Quest.

Killed a Goblin with Goblin 10/10   Other than that: This is a surprising game. Pixel art is really cute, combat don't have a lot of depth but will still be interesting after the 5-6 hours of lifespan I estimate this game to have. For the price, this is a hidden gem.

Letter games just don't work well when you're pressed with a time limit. This could have been another Bookworm Adventures, but sadly it's tedious and stupid as you're not even rewarded for making longer words on the board. If you want to learn how a factory worker in China feels, do buy this game. This game will only challenge your speed, not your wit thus making it a chore, not a pleasurable gaming experience.
Cute and Quirky (if only I could get that 7-letter word for full heal!)

It is a very simple word game. You build words from a grid, the more colored letters you use the stronger your attacks will be. If you kill the Boss of an area you can go to the next area and fight new monsters, during your journey you will level up, add new heros to your party, buy equipment and potions, but none of this seems to be really important. I enjoyed the game and will probably continue playing until i unlock every character but this is not a game for everyone.   It is repetitive and using a lot of 3 or 4 letter words is a strategy that works throughout the whole game. I wish there was a little bit more depth to it. While the heros seems different enough, the mechanics and enemies are not. There is a lot of room for improvement because every enemy feels samey, sure they maybe have different stats but you don't have to mix it up to beat them. Other games of this genre often times use special conditions for fights, for example enemies that are immune to short words or enemies that remove some of your letters the longer a fight goes. The game also doesn't have a full screen mode...

I bought this game and took off on my quest finding mulitple heroes to aid me with rending the evil from this land, dragons, skeletons, hydras, undead and trolls alike. We looted many chests, at least as many as we could, many had locks I found nigh on unfathomable, one I opened with humor. On this noble quest of mine, I traveled many miles, finding new allies as I lost the old ones in combat, they fought valiantly and they will be missed. Nonetheless we met our end, bested by a giant fungus, it's strength unimaginable, against it my defense was untenable. It was a long bloody battle, the creature suffered many wounds before I finally succumbed to mine, and as I stared up at it it's beady eyes peering down at me sprawled across the cold muddy earth I spoke my final words before it stuck the finishing blow. I looked up at it and through gritted teeth I uttered muttered the one word I could think of to deal what damage I could to this foe before I perished. Through bated breath I looked up at the mushroom, my bitter resentment unable to be hid and simply whispered...  ' s e m e n '  10/10 would play again.

I had stumpled across a wondering troll. I tried to sneak up on the beast but the sound from a breaking twig alerted the creature. He turned, Hate gleamimg from his eyes. the Traquel vibe from the forest was broke by a roaring scream. I reached for a arrow and Steaded my bow. as it flew threw the air sinking deep in the monsters chest. I fired again and again but nothing to seemed to hender his charge. just feets away I paniced and and untied my pants. quickly, I grasped my ♥♥♥♥♥ and Yanked like never before, climaxing and hitting the demon right in the eye with my ♥♥♥. He stopped right in front of me. silence. Like a tree, he fell. my heart still raced from the brute. I fell back in exhaust only to land on a trap and be showered with spikes...  10/10

It's not that I don't like it, it's just that it gets boring... uh.. no h8 m8.  I connected letters.. and make a real, existing word, but it says like TRY AGAIN. Well try again my ♥♥♥. Then I had to try 5050230423040 combinations just to get 1 word out of them all.   The graphics are pixels, as you can... see in the store page.   It's not that I DONT recommend this, its worth a try at least.  Rate: 5/10

I really like this game. Recently i've been playing heaps of online scrabble and when i stumbled across Words for Evil i thought it sounded interesting and unique, plus the art is really nostalgic of a lot of older games with pretty simple and repeditive adventuring style gameplay. So in saying that, it definetly is interesting and unique. I haven't played a game like this before. The adventuring style is basically constant sidescroll running across (what seems to be) a totally randomised landscape with different kinds of actions available that you interact with using words. There's monster battles, traps, treasure chests you unlock, blacksmith, potion man, a healing well, and new party members to be found (including santa) The music and sounds are also pretty nice and relaxing. HOWEVER- one thing i do not like about this game and keeps causing me to close it in anger is the obscurity of the words sometimes used, (that you have to unscramble to make an anagram and save yourself for example). I can understand having trickier words for more dire situations but it kind of feels like the people who made this game just found an online dictionary and added the whole lot into the game, including some of the most unfair words no one would really know unless you were specifically looking up the names of certain dog muscles or what the leader of a remote african tribe is called etc.  If the game was a bit less challenging i would definetly say to keep the complex words in, because who likes it when it's not a challenge right? Monster battles would be pretty easy to anybody, you just need to include the 'special' letters to do attacks, and that means 3 letter words are OK. However sometimes because of the randomising of encounters, you really need to get into a chest to save yourself because a well just does not seem to be coming around anytime soon, and you can only carry 3 potions maximum.  Also another problem i find is that i can't understand the weapons/armour system. there is no way to tell what weapon you are weilding and im not sure if your weapons replace when you buy them or just add to your attk stat. there is also no way at all to check your armour rating apparently.  So all in all, i would say i reccomend this game to friends because it's simple, can be pretty relaxing, and fun to play when you dont have much time to commit. Just make sure you change the difficult to Zen if you're prone to frustration easily or dont have an extensive vocabulary. I also hope the developers fix the armor and weapon issue soon.

Ever since this game popped up on the main shop front page as a new game, I was curious. I love word games. Words for Evil did not disappoint at all.  It's a walker type game, and you can quit out anytime from the level and keep the progress you've made. You make your own party out of a number of unlockable heroes, including Santa Claus (who is seriously impressive in a fight)! Essentially you're given one of a number of puzzles, depending on whether you are up against a monster, a chest, or a trap, and you have to do your best at figuring them out. It stimulates the mind, and there are RPG elements as well, such as levelling up and buying gear.  I set it on the Zen difficulty and I still find it stimulating and challenging. It's the kind of game that sucks you in and, before you know it, hours have passed. It's so easy to say 'I'll just go to the next fountain' or 'I just want to do a few more battles'.  The graphics are adorable and charming, as well as in some cases quite stunning. The sense of humour in the game is welcome and pleasant. It's also noteworthy that it has a mode for those who may be colour blind or have a deficiency in distinguishing colours, so that's a really important thing.  It's a light game that doesn't take up a lot of space or demand masses of processing power, so it's the perfect game for any system. Some words you'd expect or know may not be in the game's dictionary, but that can just add a little to the challenge. Either way, it's been perfectly delightful for me, and I have no problem recommending it to anyone who likes to think as they play a game.  Charming, fun, and really absorbing, Words for Evil also has a price that can fit into most any budget. It's worth picking up and supporting. I'd love to see more games like this, and I look forward to seeing what the developer does with Words of Evil in future.

Bought this on a whim, looked mildly interesting. I was imagining something like Typing of the dead (which i didn't really like) But it was 2 bucks so what the hell? (That's how Steam works)  Started having fun from the first few minutes onward, neat fast paced gameplay. Also has a nice little levelling system that keeps you interested. You don't have to type nearly as fast as you do in TOTD, great game to kill some time and spell some words.  I call it BATTLE BOGGLE.

I didnt really know what i was getting into when i bought it. lets say when i started it up i was intrigued. that wore off quick though and its insanely hard to pick out words to spell out quickly. also it doesnt count two letter words for some reason. unless you are good at wood search this is not a game for you.
Fun at first but becomes way too repetitive. I got bored before the end of my first game :p

Nice concept, but needs work. If you get an ability that buffs your team, you actually end up screwing yourself over because then the character doesn't deal any damage, and you end up trying to avoid triggering it (e.g. by only forming words with exactly 1 skill tile in them).

Not going to lie, for the little amount of time I've played this game so far I've had fun. Definitely beat myself up after letting my character die because I couldn't think of the word that came up on the screen. Although it does feel a bit repetitive, it's something new and creative. Definitely fun and good to kill some time.
Learned 'Quod' is a word. 10/10
Very fun!  Get's a little repetetive, and the difficulty does not seem to increase that much, maybe I need to get further into it!  Overall it's great fun though.
This game is really great, very addicting :)

This game is nice for some hours of finding words out of a box of letters but at some point it just seems to be the same over and over again, especially if you die (and if u ain't a native speaker then you will die often enough) because nothing really changes in the game; just the damage you deal and the damage enemys can tank. Since its very cheap i still recommend it for those famous 'some hours' ^^

Really? Did they even test this? Can't mute, can't change Resolution.  Would be decent for it's price if it at least the most basic option were working( in case of sound ) or even existent ( in case of graphics ). Also, only 7 letter words, meh.  Has Tradingcards which is nice. No achivements which is ok. Don't buy, there must be better typing games out there.

Scrabble meets an RPG? Yes, please! Of course, it's not so simple as that.  You're given a random assortment of letters, and sometimes, you're able to string together a good few into a word. Other times, you're left finding 3-lettered words. Also, you're going to be given an assortment of letters to use that you're not sure you're going to make an English word out of. A lot of the scrambles to save your life are exceptionally obscure. Still, I guess you learn something new every day! Give it a go. If it's not to your liking, you're only out a couple of bucks.

Words for Evil is a great mix of a Boggle-type word puzzle and an 8-bit RPG. It does seem to have a British English dictionary, so some words you might expect are not accepted, and the words to unlock the chests are often quite obscure, but I still get most of them. The progression and art style remind me of 10000000, which is a good thing. Overall it's a very well-made, fun game, and well worth the couple of bucks.
Gameplay is not that engaging, but it sure keeps you typing for one more battle. You can proceed 90% of the gameplay with just the keyboard, which is quite convenient.

Words for Evil is a fun little time-waster, but don't expect much else. The various controls work well (although getting diagonals with the mouse click-and-drag style is inconsistent). I would have very much liked to be able to check my party's status at any time, and also a bit more transparency for options. I couldn't ever see my equipment, and had no idea what the shrines did. Not being able to enter fullscreen was also annoying.  I do recommend this game if you want something small where you unlock a lot of nifty-looking sprites. If you're looking for something engaging that you can sink your teeth into, this isn't it.
Fantastic game. I previously posted some misgivings but I have learned that they were due to user error. A great take on the quick spell genre.
A fun game to zone out to. Scrabble + RPG. Definitely worth the cheap price, even better on sale!

This is a pretty awesome tiny game. If you have kids, buy this game for them to play. This is one of those learn words/typing skills/problem solving type games. Highly recommended for youngsters. But just cause it is a great game for kids doesn't mean its a baby game.  For adults it is fun too. It is kinda difficult at times and unforgiving. You will die and that's okay; it comes with the territory.  It has a cute style too.
Theres nothing i like more than to realize my english level is in fact not smarter than a fifth grader. 10/Theres only 1 word for evil
If you are thinking of getting this game, please get Letter Quest: Grimms Journey instead. Much, much better in everyway. Graphics, gameplay, upgrades..... all much better.

So I haven't really sunk my teeth into this yet, but so far this game has made me feel like a total uneducated swine. I finally got to a point where I started having characters die, and those 7 letter word puzzles more or less ended me.  Every time I come across a treasure chest I find myself saying 'That's a ♥♥♥♥ing word?'   This game is cheap, fun and it expands your vocab. Clearly not for everyone.  But if you like spelling (and quickly at that) type games you will enjoy this.  10/10 will continue to feel like an uneducated swine for hours to come.

This game is good, some people complain about the fights being too quick and you can't tell what's happening but that only adds to the hype of finding a new word in my opinion. For only $3 I think it's a pretty good deal when there's games out there that are worse but still more expensive just because they are mainstream. Not to mention you get Steam Trading cards so you level your account up.

I'd like to get into this game, but I like to take time to really think deeply and plan out the words, and as soon as I'm up against a clock (straight after the tutorial basically) that's the end of it for me, so I cannot recommend it for that reason. 0.1 hours played and that's probably my lot.
Made me want to crap my pants and bake it into a cake. If this game had a zodiac sign, it would be cancer. 11/10 would randomly type letters until I win again.

This game is a great way to pass several hours of waiting time (or to play in small batches just for fun). It's about 85% word-game, 15% RPG, so if you're looking for anything other than a quirky word game, don't buy it.  If you do love word games, definitely buy it. Buy it right now. This will be a nice change from the usual. The characters and art are simple, but consistently nice, while the designs and worlds are quite varied. There are Shops (potions and armor), Treasure Chests, Traps, Healing Springs (and medicine makers who heal for a fee), run-ins with new potential party members, mysterious otherworldly callings... Aside from weak to strong enemy encounters, a great number of things can happen each time you press on, created by a random generator. I've personally found about 6 hours of unique content so far, though I've never finished a journey or completed the character/enemy index.  There are also lots of different ways the game executes its status as a word game. For instance, if death comes for any of your characters, they have one last chance to fight back - Just solve a difficult anagram for one of two effects: a full solve for healed revival, and a partial solve for a last resort counter-attack (I've never gotten the full solve...).   You can also start a new game with characters you've leveled up in previous runs. (Personal faves are Frost Wizard, River Spirit, and Pope IX. Storm Jarl gets honorable mention.)   The music is light, but pleasant, and the sound design is pretty average.  All in all, it's definitely worth the $3, and I highly recommend giving it a try.

A mixed recommendation. The game is simple and fun but unfortunately suffers from lack of clarity when it comes to equipment and the damage being dealt/taken due to your focus being on the bottom half of the screen. However with that being said the actual gameplay mechanics are well done and satisfying.
